texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: options
texts.text: options

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I'm always on the hunt for new things to learn and one of my newer interests is around trading options on the stock market. Much like technology, it becomes much easier to understand when you peel back the layers of archaic terminology, snake oil salespeople, and debunked data.
texts.text: I'm always on the hunt for new things to learn and one of my newer interests is around trading options on the stock market. Much like technology, it becomes much easier to understand when you peel back the layers of archaic terminology, snake oil salespeople, and debunked data.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Stay tuned for additional posts that go into greater detail. This post covers the basics about what an option is (and is not) and how you can compare it to other investment vehicles, like stocks.
texts.text: Stay tuned for additional posts that go into greater detail. This post covers the basics about what an option is (and is not) and how you can compare it to other investment vehicles, like stocks.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Investing in stocks
texts.text: Investing in stocks

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Most of us are likely familiar with how investing in stocks works to some extent. The process goes something like this:
texts.text: Most of us are likely familiar with how investing in stocks works to some extent. The process goes something like this:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Deposit money into a brokerage account
texts.text: Deposit money into a brokerage account

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Find a company that has good qualities for value and growth
texts.text: Find a company that has good qualities for value and growth

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Buy shares
texts.text: Buy shares

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Wait
texts.text: Wait

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If the company performs well  and  other investors also see value in the company, your investment should gain value. For example, If you buy 10 shares of a company for $100 each ($1,000 total investment), and the stock value goes up by 10%, you will have 10 shares at $110 each ($1,100 total investment).
texts.text: If the company performs well  and  other investors also see value in the company, your investment should gain value. For example, If you buy 10 shares of a company for $100 each ($1,000 total investment), and the stock value goes up by 10%, you will have 10 shares at $110 each ($1,100 total investment).

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Stocks go up very often, but they go down, too. If the stock lost 10% of its value, you would own 10 shares of a $90 stock and your total investment would fall to $900.
texts.text: Stocks go up very often, but they go down, too. If the stock lost 10% of its value, you would own 10 shares of a $90 stock and your total investment would fall to $900.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Sometimes the stock market does downright silly things and companies with great fundamentals go down, while others with horrible numbers keep going up.
texts.text: Sometimes the stock market does downright silly things and companies with great fundamentals go down, while others with horrible numbers keep going up.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: A. Gary Shilling once said:
texts.text: A. Gary Shilling once said:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Markets can remain irrational a lot longer than you and I can remain solvent.
texts.text: Markets can remain irrational a lot longer than you and I can remain solvent.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Nothing could be more true.
texts.text: Nothing could be more true.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: How are stocks traded?
texts.text: How are stocks traded?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This could be an entire post in itself, but I'll keep things simple. When you buy a stock, you're buying it from someone else. That could be another investor, a hedge fund,a mutual fund maintainer, or a massive company.
texts.text: This could be an entire post in itself, but I'll keep things simple. When you buy a stock, you're buying it from someone else. That could be another investor, a hedge fund,a mutual fund maintainer, or a massive company.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The other entity will set the price they are willing to sell some stock. This is called the  ask . Buyers in the market set the price at which they want to buy, called the  bid . When you look at the highest bid and the lowest ask for a stock at one time, that's called the  bid/ask spread  or often just  the spread .
texts.text: The other entity will set the price they are willing to sell some stock. This is called the  ask . Buyers in the market set the price at which they want to buy, called the  bid . When you look at the highest bid and the lowest ask for a stock at one time, that's called the  bid/ask spread  or often just  the spread .

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If nobody sets a bid at or equal to anyone's ask price, no stock changes hands. Either the buyer needs to raise the price that they are willing to pay or the sellers need to come down on their asking price.
texts.text: If nobody sets a bid at or equal to anyone's ask price, no stock changes hands. Either the buyer needs to raise the price that they are willing to pay or the sellers need to come down on their asking price.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Look for stocks with a narrow bid/ask spread under $0.05-$0.10. This means the stock is liquid (easily bought and sold) and you'll avoid a weird situation called  slippage , where the bid/ask spread is really wide and your trade may not execute as a good price. (Limit orders help here. More on that later.)
texts.text: Look for stocks with a narrow bid/ask spread under $0.05-$0.10. This means the stock is liquid (easily bought and sold) and you'll avoid a weird situation called  slippage , where the bid/ask spread is really wide and your trade may not execute as a good price. (Limit orders help here. More on that later.)

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: What is similar about options?
texts.text: What is similar about options?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Options have bid/ask spreads, just like stock. Options are called derivatives because they are derived from a certain stock. That stock is called the underlying , since the options depend heavily on the stock's performance. (Not every stock on the market has options, though.)
texts.text: Options have bid/ask spreads, just like stock. Options are called derivatives because they are derived from a certain stock. That stock is called the underlying , since the options depend heavily on the stock's performance. (Not every stock on the market has options, though.)

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: What is different about options?
texts.text: What is different about options?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Options are contracts. Every options contract has rights, obligations, and an expiration date.
texts.text: Options are contracts. Every options contract has rights, obligations, and an expiration date.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Buyers of options contracts have rights (things they can choose to do) and sellers have obligations (things they must do). Everything starts with a buyer or seller who wants to open a contract. Once it's open, it can be closed via different methods.
texts.text: Buyers of options contracts have rights (things they can choose to do) and sellers have obligations (things they must do). Everything starts with a buyer or seller who wants to open a contract. Once it's open, it can be closed via different methods.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: It revolves around two main types of contracts: calls and puts.
texts.text: It revolves around two main types of contracts: calls and puts.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Buying calls
texts.text: Buying calls

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you buy a call option contract, you have the right to buy shares at the price you specify, which is called the  strike price .  (You can sell calls, too, but let's keep this simple for now.)
texts.text: If you buy a call option contract, you have the right to buy shares at the price you specify, which is called the  strike price .  (You can sell calls, too, but let's keep this simple for now.)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: AMD is a popular stock for options traders and we can use it as an example. Let's say that AMD is trading at $100 per share and you think their next chip launch will be really successful. A call could help you catch some of the potential  upswing in the stock.
texts.text: AMD is a popular stock for options traders and we can use it as an example. Let's say that AMD is trading at $100 per share and you think their next chip launch will be really successful. A call could help you catch some of the potential  upswing in the stock.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's say you buy a call at a strike price of $105 for $200 and the contract expires December 13. What have you done here and what are your rights?
texts.text: Let's say you buy a call at a strike price of $105 for $200 and the contract expires December 13. What have you done here and what are your rights?

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You made a
texts.text: You made a

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You cannot trade this option after the market close on December 13.
texts.text: You cannot trade this option after the market close on December 13.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: What are the potential outcomes before expiration? Let's analyze what AMD could do during that time:
texts.text: What are the potential outcomes before expiration? Let's analyze what AMD could do during that time:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Best outcome: AMD rises to $110
texts.text: Best outcome: AMD rises to $110

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You are
texts.text: You are

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Your options contract will increase in value and you can sell it before
texts.text: Your options contract will increase in value and you can sell it before

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You can choose to
texts.text: You can choose to

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Good outcome: AMD rises to $104.99
texts.text: Good outcome: AMD rises to $104.99

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You are
texts.text: You are

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: During this time, your call option goes up in value since the stock price
texts.text: During this time, your call option goes up in value since the stock price

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You can sell your option contract for a profit before expiration.
texts.text: You can sell your option contract for a profit before expiration.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Worst outcome: AMD falls below $100
texts.text: Worst outcome: AMD falls below $100

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You are
texts.text: You are

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Your options contract will be worth a lot less since the stock price has
texts.text: Your options contract will be worth a lot less since the stock price has

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: If your options contract still has some value left, you could sell it to
texts.text: If your options contract still has some value left, you could sell it to

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: If AMD falls
texts.text: If AMD falls

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: 💣 Just in case you missed it:  you can easily lose all of your investment with options .
texts.text: 💣 Just in case you missed it:  you can easily lose all of your investment with options .

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: With stocks, a company can take a heavy loss, but you still have some value left. With options, that same scenario means your original $200 investment is completely gone.
texts.text: With stocks, a company can take a heavy loss, but you still have some value left. With options, that same scenario means your original $200 investment is completely gone.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Buying puts
texts.text: Buying puts

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Buying a put, called a long put, is a different thing entirely. You are choosing a price where you are willing to sell 100 shares of stock you own. It's a great insurance policy for stock that you own.
texts.text: Buying a put, called a long put, is a different thing entirely. You are choosing a price where you are willing to sell 100 shares of stock you own. It's a great insurance policy for stock that you own.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Going back to the AMD example, let's say you own 100 shares of AMD at $100 each. If you buy a put at $90, you have the right to sell your stock at $90 even if AMD is trading lower than $90.
texts.text: Going back to the AMD example, let's say you own 100 shares of AMD at $100 each. If you buy a put at $90, you have the right to sell your stock at $90 even if AMD is trading lower than $90.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's go back to our $100 per share AMD example and you buy a $90 put for AMD that costs $200 and expires December 13. There are some possible outcomes:
texts.text: Let's go back to our $100 per share AMD example and you buy a $90 put for AMD that costs $200 and expires December 13. There are some possible outcomes:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: AMD rises to $110
texts.text: AMD rises to $110

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Your put option will lose lots of value, but it was your insurance policy
texts.text: Your put option will lose lots of value, but it was your insurance policy

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You can sell your put as the expiration gets closer, or you can let it
texts.text: You can sell your put as the expiration gets closer, or you can let it

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: AMD drops to $90.01
texts.text: AMD drops to $90.01

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Your put will increase in value since the stock price has moved close to
texts.text: Your put will increase in value since the stock price has moved close to

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: AMD drops to $80
texts.text: AMD drops to $80

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: You can exercise your put contract and sell your 100 shares of AMD for $90
texts.text: You can exercise your put contract and sell your 100 shares of AMD for $90

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You might be asking: What happens if I think a stock will go down, I buy a put, but I don't own the underlying stock?
texts.text: You might be asking: What happens if I think a stock will go down, I buy a put, but I don't own the underlying stock?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If the stock drops, you can sell the put for a profit as the value goes up. However, if you choose to exercise it, you will have a  short position  in your brokerage account. This means you've borrowed stock from your broker and they will likely charge fees and/or interest for this.
texts.text: If the stock drops, you can sell the put for a profit as the value goes up. However, if you choose to exercise it, you will have a  short position  in your brokerage account. This means you've borrowed stock from your broker and they will likely charge fees and/or interest for this.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If AMD's price quickly rises afterwards, you will owe your brokerage the difference.  This is painful!  Just imagine borrowing 100 shares at $80 each from your broker only to see the stock fly up to $120 per share. You will owe your broker that $4,000 difference. 🥵
texts.text: If AMD's price quickly rises afterwards, you will owe your brokerage the difference.  This is painful!  Just imagine borrowing 100 shares at $80 each from your broker only to see the stock fly up to $120 per share. You will owe your broker that $4,000 difference. 🥵

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Exercising
texts.text: Exercising

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: In your personal life, I usually recommend exercising regularly. When it comes to options, exercising may not be your best bet. There are plenty of situations where exercising an options contract is the worst idea.
texts.text: In your personal life, I usually recommend exercising regularly. When it comes to options, exercising may not be your best bet. There are plenty of situations where exercising an options contract is the worst idea.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's go back to our original example about buying a call on AMD for $105 when the stock is at $100. As an example, the stock price climbs to $110 before expiration and stays there on Friday afternoon. You are excited about your profits and you tell your broker to exercise your contract.
texts.text: Let's go back to our original example about buying a call on AMD for $105 when the stock is at $100. As an example, the stock price climbs to $110 before expiration and stays there on Friday afternoon. You are excited about your profits and you tell your broker to exercise your contract.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Your broker submits the exercise request to CBOE, the options clearinghouse. The CBOE has  some detailed rules about exercising  that I highly recommend reading.
texts.text: Your broker submits the exercise request to CBOE, the options clearinghouse. The CBOE has  some detailed rules about exercising  that I highly recommend reading.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Let's say that something happens after hours at AMD that turns out to be really bad. Maybe there's a delay on new chips, an accounting irregularity, or something else. The stock crashes after hours after you have asked for the exercise. The stock could be down to $80 by that point.
texts.text: Let's say that something happens after hours at AMD that turns out to be really bad. Maybe there's a delay on new chips, an accounting irregularity, or something else. The stock crashes after hours after you have asked for the exercise. The stock could be down to $80 by that point.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Since you asked for the exercise, the stock you expected to get (100 shares at $105 each) will actually be  100 shares at $80  each by the time your exercise is finished. This is an extreme example, but always consider what can happen during the exercise process.
texts.text: Since you asked for the exercise, the stock you expected to get (100 shares at $105 each) will actually be  100 shares at $80  each by the time your exercise is finished. This is an extreme example, but always consider what can happen during the exercise process.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: For a detailed explanation of potential outcomes here, and how to avoid them, I highly recommend the  Options Expire Saturday  episode of the Theta Gang Podcast. (The podcast is excellent overall.)
texts.text: For a detailed explanation of potential outcomes here, and how to avoid them, I highly recommend the  Options Expire Saturday  episode of the Theta Gang Podcast. (The podcast is excellent overall.)

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: What's next?
texts.text: What's next?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: 👶🏻  This introduction barely scratches the surface of options contracts, so don't start trading yet.
texts.text: 👶🏻  This introduction barely scratches the surface of options contracts, so don't start trading yet.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I'm planning future posts about selling options contracts, how to choose the options to sell and buy, as well as many other ways you can gain (and lose) money with options contracts.
texts.text: I'm planning future posts about selling options contracts, how to choose the options to sell and buy, as well as many other ways you can gain (and lose) money with options contracts.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Disclaimer: Keep in mind that I am not an investment professional and you should make your own decisions around stock research and trades. Investing comes with plenty of risk and I'm the last person who should be giving anyone investment advice.  😜
texts.text: Disclaimer: Keep in mind that I am not an investment professional and you should make your own decisions around stock research and trades. Investing comes with plenty of risk and I'm the last person who should be giving anyone investment advice.  😜
